Regulating Clients’ Noise Adding in Federated Learning without Verification

Shu Hong Singapore University of Technology and Design, Singapore
shu_hong@mymail.sutd.edu.sg    Lingjie Duan Singapore University of Technology and Design, Singapore
lingjie_duan@sutd.edu.sg
Abstract

In federated learning (FL), clients cooperatively train a global model without revealing their raw data but gradients or parameters, while the local information can still be disclosed from local outputs transmitted to the parameter server. With such privacy concerns, a client may overly add artificial noise to his local updates to compromise the global model training, and we prove the selfish noise adding leads to an infinite price of anarchy (PoA). This paper proposes a novel pricing mechanism to regulate privacy-sensitive clients without verifying their parameter updates, unlike existing privacy mechanisms that assume the server’s full knowledge of added noise. Without knowing the ground truth, our mechanism reaches the social optimum to best balance the global training error and privacy loss, according to the difference between a client’s updated parameter and all clients’ average parameter. We also improve the FL convergence bound by refining the aggregation rule at the server to account for different clients’ noise variances. Moreover, we extend our pricing scheme to fit incomplete information of clients’ privacy sensitivities, ensuring their truthful type reporting and the system’s ex-ante budget balance. Simulations show that our pricing scheme greatly improves the system performance especially when clients have diverse privacy sensitivities.

I Introduction

The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies has led to the creation of enormous amounts of user data. In an effort to safeguard data privacy, decentralized machine learning approaches such as Federated Learning (FL) [1] have been proposed without sharing individuals’ raw data. During the training phase, each client periodically downloads the global model from a parameter server and updates their local model with their own data. By only transferring gradient parameters instead of raw data, data privacy can be preserved.

Sharing model updates or gradients, however, can also compromise clients’ private information, as analyzing the differences in training parameters uploaded by clients can reveal it. For example, model inverse attack [2, 3] allows training data reconstruction by matching model gradients and optimizing randomly initialized inputs. These attacks for data reconstruction or membership inference [4] are significant threats to FL security and privacy. To prevent privacy leakage, each client can add artificial noise [5, 6, 7] to the transmitted parameters. However, this approach can lead to significant training accuracy loss while making it harder for attackers to inverse the original local data.

Despite of the privacy concerns in FL, clients might also take advantage of the returned global model for benefits. For example, in the “cross-silo” scenario of FL [1] (e.g., in medical and financial institutions), an AI model is trained on clients with large amounts of data and clients also care about the convergence performance. Given both privacy concerns and model training benefits, Noble et al. [8] and Sun et al. [9] studied the tradeoff between utility and privacy for FL. It is also critical to study the clients’ selfish noise-adding strategy based on each individual’s preference of learning performance and privacy requirement.

Our analysis of the worst-case ratio of social costs under clients’ selfish behavior and the social optimum prompts us to study incentive mechanisms to regulate clients’ noise adding and approach the social optimum. Existing works on noise-adding privacy protection mechanisms [5, 6, 7]) assume that the server can verify and know all clients’ contributions, which is challenging to achieve in practice without access to clients’ local data. In contrast, our paper incentivizes honest contributions from clients with performance-based pricing schemes that penalize individuals based on the difference between their local parameters and the average parameter benchmark of all clients. Although the average benchmark may not be the ground truth, we prove its effectiveness in preventing clients from adding excessive local noise.

Specifically, considering clients’ varying privacy sensitivities, we analyse their equilibrium strategies under a properly improved weighted aggregation rule, and optimally design the price charged to each client for achieving the social optimum. Additionally, we extend our pricing scheme to account for incomplete information about clients’ privacy sensitivity, where some clients may not truthfully report their types. Our refined pricing mechanism includes a reward function, a penalty function, and a compensation payment to ensure truthful reporting, social efficiency, and FL system’s ex-ante budget balance. Simulation results demonstrate significant improvement in equilibrium performance, particularly when clients have diverse privacy sensitivities.

The rest of this paper is structured as follows. In Section II we introduce the system model and problem formulation. In Sections III and IV we present the equilibrium analysis and pricing mechanism design under complete and incomplete information of clients’ privacy sensitivity types, respectively. We conclude the paper in Section V. Due to page limit, we put the detailed proofs in the on-line technical report[10].

II System Model and Problem Formulation

In this section, we introduce the system model and formulate the privacy-preserving problem with noise adding.

II-A Preliminaries

First, we present preliminaries about backgrounds on federated learning (FL) and differential privacy (DP).

Federated Learning. Consider an FL system consisting of one parameter server (PS) and N𝑁N clients in set 𝒩={1,2,⋯,N}𝒩12⋯𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\cdots,N\}. Each client i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N} holds the local database 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and aims to iteratively minimize a local loss function Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} by training the local parameter vector 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}, i.e.,

𝐰i=arg⁡min𝐰⁡Fi​(𝐰,𝒟i).subscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐰subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{i}=\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}}F_{i}(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{D}_{i}).

The goal of the server is to learn a global model over data at all N𝑁N distributed clients. The problem to minimize the global loss function F𝐹F is:

𝐰∗=arg⁡min𝐰⁡F​(𝐰,𝒟)=arg⁡min𝐰​∑i∈𝒩ρi​Fi​(𝐰,𝒟i),superscript𝐰subscript𝐰𝐹𝐰𝒟subscript𝐰subscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖\displaystyle\mathbf{w}^{*}=\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}}F(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{D})=\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\rho_{i}F_{i}(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{D}_{i}), (1)

where 𝒟=∪i∈𝒩𝒟i𝒟subscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}=\cup_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\mathcal{D}_{i} includes the datasets from all N𝑁N clients. Formally, in each iteration the server aggregates the updated parameters received from all clients as

𝐰¯​(𝝆,𝐰)=∑i∈𝒩ρi​𝐰i,¯𝐰𝝆𝐰subscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖\displaystyle{\bar{\mathbf{w}}}(\bm{\rho},\mathbf{w})=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\rho_{i}\mathbf{w}_{i}, (2)

where 𝐰¯¯𝐰\bar{\mathbf{w}} is the parameter vector aggregated at the server and ρi≥0subscript𝜌𝑖0\rho_{i}\geq 0 is the weightage parameter for aggregation.

Each training iteration of such an FL system usually contains the following three steps: clients’ local training and updating, global aggregation at the server, and parameter broadcast to clients. After a sufficient number of training iterations (say, T𝑇T rounds) and update exchanges between the server and the distributed clients, the solution to the optimization problem (1) converges to that of the global model. Thus, the training accuracy loss can be defined as the expected global error, i.e.,

ℒu=𝔼​{F​(𝐰(T))−F​(𝐰∗)},superscriptℒ𝑢𝔼𝐹superscript𝐰𝑇𝐹superscript𝐰\mathcal{L}^{u}=\mathbb{E}\{F({\mathbf{w}}^{(T)})-F({\mathbf{w}}^{*})\}, (3)

which depends on the aggregation rule in (2). To quantify the convergence bound for the learning, we here make some typical assumptions about the loss functions.

Assumption 1.

The global loss function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) is convex and LFsubscript𝐿𝐹L_{F}-smooth, i.e., ‖∇F​(𝐱)−∇F​(𝐱′)‖2≤LF​‖𝐱−𝐱′‖2,∀𝐱,𝐱′subscriptnorm∇𝐹𝐱∇𝐹superscript𝐱′2subscript𝐿𝐹subscriptnorm𝐱superscript𝐱′2for-all𝐱superscript𝐱′\left\|\nabla F(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right\|_{2}\leq L_{F}\left\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right\|_{2},\forall\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}.

As in most of the literature (e.g., [6, 17]), the convergence or accuracy error of the FL process is difficult to quantify and is analysed using the convergence bound. Let ℒ¯u​(𝝈,𝐰¯)superscript¯ℒ𝑢𝝈¯𝐰\bar{\mathcal{L}}^{u}(\bm{\sigma},{\bar{\mathbf{w}}}) denote the upper bound of the expected global error ℒusuperscriptℒ𝑢{\mathcal{L}}^{u} in (3), then clients will take it into account when making noise-adding decisions in each iteration. Note that the bound of the training accuracy loss function is for all FL clients, and depends on all clients’ noise-adding strategies as well as the server’s aggregation rule.

Differential Privacy. Despite that all clients locally compute training gradient parameter 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} and send it to the server, attacks such as gradient inverse attack[2, 3] might disclose the original training data without accessing the datasets. As proposed in [13], (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-Differential Privacy (DP) provides a criterion for privacy preservation of distributed data processing systems, and the definition is formally given as follows.

Definition 1 (Differential Privacy).

A randomized algorithm 𝒫:𝒳→ℛ:𝒫→𝒳ℛ\mathcal{P}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} with domain 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and range ℛℛ\mathcal{R} is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differentially-private if for all 𝒮⊆ℛ𝒮ℛ\mathcal{S}\subseteq\mathcal{R} and for all x,y∈𝒳𝑥𝑦𝒳x,y\in\mathcal{X} such that ‖x−y‖1≤1subscriptnorm𝑥𝑦11||x-y||_{1}\leq 1:

Pr⁡[𝒫​(x)∈𝒮]≤eε​Pr⁡[𝒫​(y)∈𝒮]+δ,Pr𝒫𝑥𝒮superscript𝑒𝜀Pr𝒫𝑦𝒮𝛿\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{P}(x)\in\mathcal{S}]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{P}(y)\in\mathcal{S}]+\delta,

where ε𝜀\varepsilon is the distinguishable bound of all outputs on adjacent datasets x𝑥x and y𝑦y in a database, and δ𝛿\delta represents the event that the ratio of the probabilities for two adjacent datasets x𝑥x and y𝑦y cannot be bounded by eεsuperscript𝑒𝜀e^{\varepsilon} after the algorithm 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}.

Given this privacy definition, we aim to provide useful privacy protection to the transmitted parameters 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} and thus the raw dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, as in [6]. Specifically, in the t𝑡t-th round, suppose client i𝑖i adds Gaussian noise 𝐧i∼𝒩​(0,σi2)similar-tosubscript𝐧𝑖𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\mathbf{n}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{i}^{2}) locally to the transmitted parameter 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}, as

𝐰~i(t)=𝐰i(t)+𝐧i(t).superscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐧𝑖𝑡\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}^{(t)}={\mathbf{w}}_{i}^{(t)}+{\mathbf{n}}_{i}^{(t)}.

Under the DP definition and the Gaussian mechanism, the privacy algorithm 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} outputs the noise-adding parameter 𝐰~isubscript~𝐰𝑖\tilde{{\mathbf{w}}}_{i} and provides a privacy guarantee to clients’ transmitted parameters 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}. Following Definition 1, [13] also defines a quantity to measure the privacy loss of the privacy algorithm after observing the output 𝐰~isubscript~𝐰𝑖\tilde{{\mathbf{w}}}_{i} as o𝑜o, i.e.,

ℒip=ln⁡(Pr⁡[𝒫​(𝐰i)=o]Pr⁡[𝒫​(𝐰i′)=o]),superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑝Pr𝒫subscript𝐰𝑖𝑜Pr𝒫subscriptsuperscript𝐰′𝑖𝑜\mathcal{L}_{i}^{p}=\ln\left(\frac{\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{P}({{\mathbf{w}}}_{i})=o]}{\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{P}({{\mathbf{w}}}^{\prime}_{i})=o]}\right),

where 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖{{\mathbf{w}}}_{i} and 𝐰i′subscriptsuperscript𝐰′𝑖{{\mathbf{w}}}^{\prime}_{i} are two adjacent local parameters (without noise) and ℒipsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑝\mathcal{L}_{i}^{p} can be positive or negative. Then we have

Pr⁡(ℒip≤εi)>1−δ.Prsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑝subscript𝜀𝑖1𝛿\operatorname{Pr}(\mathcal{L}_{i}^{p}\leq\varepsilon_{i})>1-\delta.

That is, the privacy loss ℒipsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑝\mathcal{L}_{i}^{p} is upper-bounded by εisubscript𝜀𝑖\varepsilon_{i} with a large probability (given δ𝛿\delta is small). Thus, we use ℒ¯ip=εisuperscriptsubscript¯ℒ𝑖𝑝subscript𝜀𝑖\bar{\mathcal{L}}_{i}^{p}=\varepsilon_{i} as the approximate bound of privacy loss for client i𝑖i, to be a privacy factor affecting the client’s noise-adding decision. Equivalently, we have the bound of the privacy loss

ℒ¯ip​(σi)=c​Sσisubscriptsuperscript¯ℒ𝑝𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖𝑐𝑆subscript𝜎𝑖\bar{\mathcal{L}}^{p}_{i}(\sigma_{i})=\frac{cS}{\sigma_{i}} (4)

from the Gaussian mechanism for client i𝑖i.

II-B Our Mechanism Design at the Server

Given the bounds for the global training error ℒ¯usuperscript¯ℒ𝑢\bar{\mathcal{L}}^{u} and privacy loss ℒ¯ipsuperscriptsubscript¯ℒ𝑖𝑝\bar{\mathcal{L}}_{i}^{p} in (4), we denote 𝜶={αi∈𝒢=[0,1]|i∈𝒩}𝜶conditional-setsubscript𝛼𝑖𝒢01𝑖𝒩\bm{\alpha}=\{\alpha_{i}\in\mathcal{G}=[0,1]|i\in\mathcal{N}\} as the N𝑁N clients’ privacy sensitivity types, which are private information and need to be reported by themselves to the server. Each client i𝑖i minimizes a total cost function Jisubscript𝐽𝑖J_{i}:

Ji​(αi,σi,𝝈−i,𝐰¯)subscript𝐽𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝝈𝑖¯𝐰\displaystyle J_{i}(\alpha_{i},\sigma_{i},\bm{\sigma}_{-i},{\bar{\mathbf{w}}}) =(1−αi)​ℒ¯u​(𝝈,𝐰¯)+αi​ℒ¯ip​(σi),absent1subscript𝛼𝑖superscript¯ℒ𝑢𝝈¯𝐰subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsubscript¯ℒ𝑖𝑝subscript𝜎𝑖\displaystyle=(1-\alpha_{i})\bar{\mathcal{L}}^{u}(\bm{\sigma},{\bar{\mathbf{w}}})+\alpha_{i}\bar{\mathcal{L}}_{i}^{p}(\sigma_{i}), (5)

by designing the noise scale σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} based on their own privacy sensitivity types αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i}. Note that such a type αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} is a constant parameter, to measure a client’s individual preference on the utility-privacy tradeoff[18].

After receiving 𝐰~isubscript~𝐰𝑖\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i} with the artificial noise, the server aggregates all the local parameters as a weighted sum in (2). With the aim to utilize pricing schemes for achieving better social performance at the server, a deterministic mechanism f𝑓f outputs a pricing scheme 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} according to clients’ reporting 𝜶^bold-^𝜶\bm{\hat{\alpha}} of their privacy sensitivities and local training outcomes 𝐰~~𝐰\tilde{\mathbf{w}}, i.e., f​(𝜶^,𝐰~)={𝐏​(𝜶^,𝐰~)}𝑓bold-^𝜶~𝐰𝐏bold-^𝜶~𝐰f(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})=\{\mathbf{P}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})\}.

Considering the server’s pricing scheme, each client i𝑖i’s cost function Ji​(αi,σi,𝝈−i,𝐰¯)subscript𝐽𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝝈𝑖¯𝐰J_{i}(\alpha_{i},\sigma_{i},\bm{\sigma}_{-i},{\bar{\mathbf{w}}}) in (5) can be modified as

J¯i​(f​(𝜶^,𝐰~)|𝝈,𝜶)=Ji​(αi,σi,𝝈−i,𝐰¯)+Pi​(𝜶^,𝐰~)=(1−αi)​ℒ¯u​(𝝈,𝐰¯)+αi​ℒ¯ip​(σi)+Pi​(𝜶^,𝐰~),subscript¯𝐽𝑖conditional𝑓bold-^𝜶~𝐰𝝈𝜶subscript𝐽𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝝈𝑖¯𝐰subscript𝑃𝑖bold-^𝜶~𝐰1subscript𝛼𝑖superscript¯ℒ𝑢𝝈¯𝐰subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsubscript¯ℒ𝑖𝑝subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖bold-^𝜶~𝐰\bar{J}_{i}(f(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})|\bm{\sigma},\bm{\alpha})=J_{i}(\alpha_{i},\sigma_{i},\bm{\sigma}_{-i},{\bar{\mathbf{w}}})+P_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})\\ =(1-\alpha_{i})\bar{\mathcal{L}}^{u}(\bm{\sigma},{\bar{\mathbf{w}}})+\alpha_{i}\bar{\mathcal{L}}_{i}^{p}(\sigma_{i})+P_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}),

where Pi​(𝜶^,𝐰~)subscript𝑃𝑖bold-^𝜶~𝐰P_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) is the ex-post price charged to client i𝑖i after his reporting and computation.

FL clients are self-interested and cost-driven, such that they will respond to the pricing with the best noise-adding strategies to minimize their costs. Next, we explicitly model the interaction between FL clients and the server in a two-stage dynamic Bayesian game as follows.

  • •

    In Stage I, the server announces the number of whole training rounds or end-time T𝑇T, the mechanism including the global aggregation rule w¯​(𝐰~,𝜶^)¯w~𝐰bold-^𝜶\bar{\textbf{w}}(\tilde{\mathbf{w}},\bm{\hat{\alpha}}) and the (ex-post) pricing scheme 𝑷​(𝜶^,𝐰~)𝑷bold-^𝜶~𝐰\bm{P}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) to clients. The pricing schemes aim to incentivize truthful reporting of clients’ types and socially optimal strategies. The clients’ cost functions Jisubscript𝐽𝑖J_{i}’s in (5) are common knowledge.

  • •

    In Stage II, clients report their types α^isubscript^𝛼𝑖{\hat{\alpha}_{i}}’s to the server and upload parameters 𝐰~isubscript~𝐰𝑖\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i} with noise level σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} in distributed computation. Correspondingly, the server returns the global parameter 𝐰¯¯𝐰{\bar{\mathbf{w}}} and charges a price Pi​(𝜶^,𝐰~)subscript𝑃𝑖bold-^𝜶~𝐰P_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) to each client i𝑖i at the end of each iteration.

Given that clients’ privacy sensitivity αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i}’s are private information, for achieving better social performance, the mechanism design at the server needs to be truthful and efficient. Next we formally define the truthfulness.

Definition 2 (Truthfulness).

A mechanism is truthful if no agent can benefit from misreporting his type i𝑖i. Formally, given client i𝑖i, type profile 𝛂={αi,𝛂−i}∈𝒢N𝛂subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛂𝑖superscript𝒢𝑁\bm{\alpha}=\{\alpha_{i},\bm{\alpha}_{-i}\}\in\mathcal{G}^{N}, and any misreported type α^i∈𝒢subscript^𝛼𝑖𝒢{\hat{\alpha}_{i}}\in\mathcal{G}, it holds that

J¯i​(f​(αi,𝜶−i,𝐰~)|𝝈,𝜶)≤J¯i​(f​(α^i,𝜶−i,𝐰~)|𝝈,𝜶).subscript¯𝐽𝑖conditional𝑓subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝜶𝑖~𝐰𝝈𝜶subscript¯𝐽𝑖conditional𝑓subscript^𝛼𝑖subscript𝜶𝑖~𝐰𝝈𝜶\displaystyle\bar{J}_{i}(f(\alpha_{i},\bm{\alpha}_{-i},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})|\bm{\sigma},\bm{\alpha})\leq\bar{J}_{i}(f({\hat{\alpha}_{i}},\bm{\alpha}_{-i},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})|\bm{\sigma},\bm{\alpha}).

We are also interested in designing truthful mechanisms that perform well with respect to minimizing the social cost. Define the social cost of a mechanism f​(𝜶^,𝐰~)𝑓bold-^𝜶~𝐰f(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) as the sum of costs of N𝑁N agents, i.e.,

S​C​(f​(𝜶^,𝐰~)|𝝈,𝜶)𝑆𝐶conditional𝑓bold-^𝜶~𝐰𝝈𝜶\displaystyle SC(f(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})|\bm{\sigma},\bm{\alpha}) =∑i∈𝒩Ji​(αi,𝝈,𝐰¯).absentsubscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝐽𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖𝝈¯𝐰\displaystyle=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}J_{i}(\alpha_{i},\bm{\sigma},{\bar{\mathbf{w}}}). (6)

Let O​P​T​(𝜶)𝑂𝑃𝑇𝜶OPT(\bm{\alpha}) denote the optimal minimum social cost, i.e.,

O​P​T​(𝜶)=min𝝈⁡S​C​(f​(𝜶^,𝐰~)|𝝈,𝜶).𝑂𝑃𝑇𝜶subscript𝝈𝑆𝐶conditional𝑓bold-^𝜶~𝐰𝝈𝜶OPT(\bm{\alpha})=\min_{\bm{\sigma}}SC(f(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})|\bm{\sigma},\bm{\alpha}).

Then we use the concept of price of anarchy (PoA) to tell the maximum efficiency loss due to clients’ selfish behavior by adding too much noise or misreporting types.

Definition 3 (Price of Anarchy).

The ratio between the social cost and the socially optimal cost for mechanism f​(𝛂^,𝐰~)𝑓bold-^𝛂~𝐰f(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) is

γ=S​C​(f​(𝜶^,𝐰~)|𝝈,𝜶)O​P​T​(𝜶)≥1.𝛾𝑆𝐶conditional𝑓bold-^𝜶~𝐰𝝈𝜶𝑂𝑃𝑇𝜶1\gamma=\frac{SC(f(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})|\bm{\sigma},\bm{\alpha})}{OPT(\bm{\alpha})}\geq 1.

The Price of Anarchy (PoA) is defined as the maximum of the ratio by scanning through all possible parameters:

P​o​A=max𝜶,N,c,S,T,λF,LF⁡γ.𝑃𝑜𝐴subscript𝜶𝑁𝑐𝑆𝑇subscript𝜆𝐹subscript𝐿𝐹𝛾PoA=\max_{\bm{\alpha},N,c,S,T,\lambda_{F},L_{F}}\gamma.

The PoA definition describes an efficiency gap between clients’ equilibrium strategy and the social optimum. If it is non-small, it motivates us to design a mechanism which approaches or even achieves social optimum with γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1. Next, we will analyse clients’ equilibrium strategy and prepare the server’s mechanism design.

III Game Analysis and Mechanism Design under Complete information

In this section, we assume that all clients’ types are known to the parameter server (or equivalently, α^i=αisubscript^𝛼𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖{\hat{\alpha}_{i}}=\alpha_{i}), which may be done by checking their historical activities on similar FL tasks. In this scenario, the server’s mechanism f​(𝜶^,𝐰~)𝑓bold-^𝜶~𝐰f(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) reduces to a function of parameters 𝐰~~𝐰\tilde{\mathbf{w}}. We derive clients’ equilibrium noise-adding strategy after introducing a properly improved aggregation rule at the server, and then we design a mechanism to achieve the minimum social cost.

III-A Improved Aggregation Rule at the Server

Given the clients’ training accuracy loss ℒ¯u​(𝝈,𝐰¯)superscript¯ℒ𝑢𝝈¯𝐰\bar{\mathcal{L}}^{u}(\bm{\sigma},{\bar{\mathbf{w}}}) in (5) depends on the server’s aggregation rule, we first consider an aggregation rule 𝐰¯​(𝜶^,𝐰~)=𝐰¯​(𝜶,𝐰~)¯𝐰bold-^𝜶~𝐰¯𝐰𝜶~𝐰{\bar{\mathbf{w}}}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})={\bar{\mathbf{w}}}(\bm{\alpha},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) from (2) to ensure the training convergence performance.

The standard aggregation rule in the FedAvg algorithm [17] uses a simple mean aggregation as

𝐰¯m​e​a​n​(𝜶,𝐰~)=∑i∈𝒩𝐰~iN,superscript¯𝐰𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛𝜶~𝐰subscript𝑖𝒩subscript~𝐰𝑖𝑁\bar{\mathbf{w}}^{mean}(\bm{{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})=\frac{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}}{N}, (7)

which does not take clients’ strategic behaviours or added noise variances into consideration. Alternatively, predicting any client i𝑖i’ strategy with distinct standard deviation σi​(αi)subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖\sigma_{i}(\alpha_{i}) from cost function (5), we properly use the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) for better aggregation with 𝜶^=𝜶bold-^𝜶𝜶\bm{\hat{\alpha}}=\bm{\alpha}:

𝐰¯M​L​E​(𝜶,𝐰~)=∑i∈𝒩𝐰~iσi2​(αi)∑i∈𝒩1σi2​(αi).superscript¯𝐰𝑀𝐿𝐸𝜶~𝐰subscript𝑖𝒩subscript~𝐰𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑖𝒩1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑖{\bar{\mathbf{w}}}^{MLE}(\bm{{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})=\frac{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}}{\sigma_{i}^{2}(\alpha_{i})}}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{1}{\sigma_{i}^{2}(\alpha_{i})}}. (8)
Proposition 1.

With the MLE aggregation rule in (8), we give the upper bound of the training accuracy loss function ℒusuperscriptℒ𝑢{\mathcal{L}}^{u} in (3) as

ℒ¯u​(𝝈,𝐰¯)=κ​ΔM​L​E​(𝝈)​(1+12​LF​ΔM​L​E​(𝝈)),superscript¯ℒ𝑢𝝈¯𝐰𝜅superscriptΔ𝑀𝐿𝐸𝝈112subscript𝐿𝐹superscriptΔ𝑀𝐿𝐸𝝈\bar{\mathcal{L}}^{u}(\bm{\sigma},{\bar{\mathbf{w}}})=\kappa\Delta^{MLE}(\bm{\sigma})\left(1+\frac{1}{2L_{F}}\Delta^{MLE}(\bm{\sigma})\right), (9)

where κ=16​‖𝐰0−𝐰∗‖2𝜅16subscriptnormsuperscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2\kappa=16||\mathbf{w}^{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}||_{2} with T=LFΔ​‖𝐰0−𝐰∗‖2𝑇subscript𝐿𝐹Δsubscriptnormsuperscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2T=\frac{L_{F}}{\Delta}||\mathbf{w}^{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}||_{2}, step size η=1/LF𝜂1subscript𝐿𝐹\eta=1/L_{F}, ΔM​L​E=(∑i=1Nσi−2)−12superscriptΔ𝑀𝐿𝐸superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖212\Delta^{MLE}=(\sum_{i=1}^{N}\sigma_{i}^{-2})^{-\frac{1}{2}} measures the bound of the expected error 𝔼​|μ^−μ|𝔼^𝜇𝜇\mathbb{E}|\hat{\mu}-\mu| achieved by MLE. Our improved aggregation rule in (8) leads to a smaller convergence bound than the mean aggregation in (7).

Proposition 1 guides us to choose the MLE aggregation rule for better convergence performance at the server.

III-B Clients’ Strategy under Equilibrium and Social Optimum

By substituting (9) into the cost function (without pricing) for client i𝑖i in (5), the cost for client i𝑖i becomes

Ji​(σi,𝝈−i)subscript𝐽𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝝈𝑖\displaystyle J_{i}(\sigma_{i},\bm{\sigma}_{-i}) =κ​(1−αi)​ΔM​L​E​(𝝈)​(1+ΔM​L​E​(𝝈)2​LF)+αi​c​Sσi.absent𝜅1subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptΔ𝑀𝐿𝐸𝝈1superscriptΔ𝑀𝐿𝐸𝝈2subscript𝐿𝐹subscript𝛼𝑖𝑐𝑆subscript𝜎𝑖\displaystyle=\kappa(1-\alpha_{i})\Delta^{MLE}(\bm{\sigma})(1+\frac{\Delta^{MLE}(\bm{\sigma})}{2L_{F}})+\frac{\alpha_{i}cS}{\sigma_{i}}.

By minimizing the individual’s and social costs, we give the equilibrium and social optimal noise-adding strategies for client i𝑖i.

Proposition 2.

Given that the server chooses the MLE aggregation rule in (8), the equilibrium noise level σi∗superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i}^{*} for client i𝑖i with privacy sensitivity type αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} is the unique solution to

κ​(1−αi)​(∑j∈𝒩σj−2)−32​(∑j∈𝒩σj−2)−12+LFLF=αi​c​S​σi,𝜅1subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗𝒩superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑗232superscriptsubscript𝑗𝒩superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑗212subscript𝐿𝐹subscript𝐿𝐹subscript𝛼𝑖𝑐𝑆subscript𝜎𝑖\displaystyle\kappa(1-\alpha_{i})(\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}\sigma_{j}^{-2})^{-\frac{3}{2}}\frac{\left(\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}\sigma_{j}^{-2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}+L_{F}}{L_{F}}=\alpha_{i}cS\sigma_{i}, (10)

while under social optimum, the noise level σi∗∗superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖absent\sigma_{i}^{**} for client i𝑖i is the unique solution to

κ​(∑i∈𝒩(1−αi))​(∑j∈𝒩σj−2)−32​(∑j∈𝒩σj−2)−12+LFLF=αi​c​S​σi.𝜅subscript𝑖𝒩1subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗𝒩superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑗232superscriptsubscript𝑗𝒩superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑗212subscript𝐿𝐹subscript𝐿𝐹subscript𝛼𝑖𝑐𝑆subscript𝜎𝑖\kappa\left(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}(1-\alpha_{i})\right)(\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}\sigma_{j}^{-2})^{-\frac{3}{2}}\frac{\left(\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}\sigma_{j}^{-2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}+L_{F}}{L_{F}}\\ =\alpha_{i}cS\sigma_{i}. (11)

To show the maximum gap of social costs defined in (6) under clients’ equilibrium in (10) and the social optimum in (11), we use the PoA definition in Definition 3.

Proposition 3.

Price of anarchy under complete information goes to infinity under the worst case.

III-C Pricing Mechanism for Achieving Social Optimum

To incentivize client i𝑖i to choose noise level σi∗∗superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖absent\sigma_{i}^{**} rather than σi∗superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i}^{*}, we design the ex-post pricing scheme 𝐏​(𝜶^,𝐰~)=𝐏​(𝜶,𝐰~)𝐏bold-^𝜶~𝐰𝐏𝜶~𝐰\mathbf{P}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})=\mathbf{P}(\bm{\alpha},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) to impose penalty to clients who add too much noise to their local parameters 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}’s.

Definition 4 (Pricing Mechanism under Complete Information).

Under complete information of clients’ types 𝛂𝛂\bm{\alpha}, the mechanism f​(𝛂,𝐰~)={𝐏​(𝛂,𝐰~)}𝑓𝛂~𝐰𝐏𝛂~𝐰f({\bm{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})=\{\mathbf{P}(\bm{\alpha},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})\} decides pricing function

Pi​(𝜶,𝐰~)subscript𝑃𝑖𝜶~𝐰\displaystyle P_{i}(\bm{\alpha},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) =βi∗​(𝜶)​(𝐰~i−1N​∑i=1N𝐰~i)2−q,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝜶superscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript~𝐰𝑖2𝑞\displaystyle=\beta_{i}^{*}(\bm{\alpha})\left(\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}\right)^{2}-q,

charged to client i𝑖i, where the penalty coefficient is

βi∗​(𝜶)=N2​∑j≠i,j∈𝒩(1−αj)​αj​c​S2​(N−1)2​(∑i∈𝒩(1−αi)​(σi∗∗)3),superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝜶superscript𝑁2subscriptformulae-sequence𝑗𝑖𝑗𝒩1subscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝛼𝑗𝑐𝑆2superscript𝑁12subscript𝑖𝒩1subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖absent3\beta_{i}^{*}(\bm{\alpha})=\frac{N^{2}\sum_{j\neq i,j\in\mathcal{N}}(1-\alpha_{j})\alpha_{j}cS}{2(N-1)^{2}(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}(1-\alpha_{i})(\sigma_{i}^{**})^{3})}, (12)

and the compensation payment is

q=2​(N−1)2N​∑i∈𝒩βi∗​(𝜶)​σi∗∗,𝑞2superscript𝑁12𝑁subscript𝑖𝒩superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝜶superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖absent\displaystyle q=\frac{2(N-1)^{2}}{N}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\beta_{i}^{*}(\bm{\alpha})\sigma_{i}^{**},

where σi∗∗superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖absent\sigma_{i}^{**} is given in (11).

Proposition 4.

Under complete information, our pricing mechanism in Definition 4 simultaneously reaches the social optimum with γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 and ex-ante budget balance.

Though our pricing scheme with (12) does not verify each client’s noise/contribution and simply compares each client’s performance to the noisy average benchmark, it already achieves the social optimum. Even when all clients have the same sensitivity types, they worry their randomly computed parameters to be an outlier and do not dare to add much noise. Ex-ante budget balance for each client (achieved by compensation q𝑞q) is an important property in economics[19] and helps ensure long-term client participation.

Without a pricing scheme, Fig. 1 shows a substantial increase in social cost as the variance of αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} rises. This trend can be attributed to the increasingly diverse objectives of varying clients, leading to differences in their training goals and privacy concerns. Self-interested client behavior to protect privacy leads to more noise and higher training accuracy loss. However, our pricing scheme maintains lower social costs due to clients’ sensitivity to penalties.

IV Game Analysis and Mechanism Design under Incomplete information

Under incomplete information, all clients’ real types 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} are private information while the only common knowledge is the random type distribution αi∼𝒢​(α)similar-tosubscript𝛼𝑖𝒢𝛼\alpha_{i}\sim\mathcal{G}(\alpha) in [0,1]01[0,1]. We propose that the server asks each client i𝑖i to report his type α^isubscript^𝛼𝑖{\hat{\alpha}_{i}}, which might not be truthful due to clients’ selfish behaviours. The Bayesian game for server-client interaction is formulated as in Section II-B. We refine our pricing scheme in Definition 4 to fit.

Definition 5 (Pricing Mechanism under Incomplete Information).

Under incomplete information of clients’ types 𝛂𝛂\bm{\alpha}, our mechanism f​(𝛂^,𝐰~)={𝐏​(𝛂^,𝐰~)}𝑓bold-^𝛂~𝐰𝐏bold-^𝛂~𝐰f(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})=\{\mathbf{P}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})\} decides:

Pi​(𝜶^,𝐰~)subscript𝑃𝑖bold-^𝜶~𝐰\displaystyle P_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) =pi​(𝜶^,𝐰~)−ri​(𝜶^)−q.absentsubscript𝑝𝑖bold-^𝜶~𝐰subscript𝑟𝑖bold-^𝜶𝑞\displaystyle={p}_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})-r_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}})-q.
  • •

    The penalty pi​(𝜶^,𝐰~)subscript𝑝𝑖bold-^𝜶~𝐰p_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}}) aims to incentivize client i𝑖i to update local parameters with only socially optimal noise variance σi∗∗superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖absent{\sigma}_{i}^{**}. It takes a similar form from Definition 4 as pi​(𝜶^,𝐰~)=βi​(𝜶^)​(𝐰~i−1N​∑i=1N𝐰~i)2subscript𝑝𝑖bold-^𝜶~𝐰subscript𝛽𝑖bold-^𝜶superscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript~𝐰𝑖2p_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}},\tilde{\mathbf{w}})=\beta_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}})\left(\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}\right)^{2}, yet here we need to design new parameters 𝜷​(𝜶^)𝜷bold-^𝜶\bm{\beta}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}}) under incomplete information.

  • •

    The reward function ri​(𝜶^)subscript𝑟𝑖bold-^𝜶r_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}}) is to incentivize client i𝑖i’s truthful reporting of αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} under incomplete information.

  • •

    The constant compensation payment q𝑞q is refunded to each client to make the FL system ex-ante budget balanced.

Next, we analyse the Bayesian game between clients and the server under incomplete information by backward induction.

IV-B Clients’ Equilibrium Strategies with Binary Type Values

To simplify the analysis, we limit clients’ i.i.d. private type distribution of αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} to be two discrete values in {αL,αH}subscript𝛼𝐿subscript𝛼𝐻\{\alpha_{L},\alpha_{H}\} with 0≤αL<αH≤10subscript𝛼𝐿subscript𝛼𝐻10\leq\alpha_{L}<\alpha_{H}\leq 1, though similar analysis methods holds for the continuous distribution. The common knowledge is the proportion η𝜂\eta of all clients’ types:

αi={αL, with probability ​η,αH, with probability ​1−η.subscript𝛼𝑖casessubscript𝛼𝐿 with probability 𝜂subscript𝛼𝐻 with probability 1𝜂\alpha_{i}=\begin{cases}\alpha_{L},&\text{ with probability }\eta,\\ \alpha_{H},&\text{ with probability }1-\eta.\end{cases}

Considering the deterministic reporting strategy α^i∈{αL,αH}subscript^𝛼𝑖subscript𝛼𝐿subscript𝛼𝐻{\hat{\alpha}_{i}}\in\{\alpha_{L},\alpha_{H}\}, clients may truthfully report or misreport. Due to the symmetry of both types of clients, there are three cases for all clients’ type reporting strategies 𝜶^bold-^𝜶\bm{\hat{\alpha}} in general.

IV-B1 Case 1

all clients reports the same type αLsubscript𝛼𝐿\alpha_{L} or αHsubscript𝛼𝐻\alpha_{H}, i.e., α^​(αL)=α^​(αH)∈{αL,αH}^𝛼subscript𝛼𝐿^𝛼subscript𝛼𝐻subscript𝛼𝐿subscript𝛼𝐻\hat{\alpha}(\alpha_{L})=\hat{\alpha}(\alpha_{H})\in\{\alpha_{L},\alpha_{H}\} for any i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N}.

In this case, receiving the same type reporting from all clients, the server has to assign the same weight with ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1 in the aggregation rule in (2). Also, the reward function and penalty coefficient are indistinctive among all agents.

The detailed forms of Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i} (i=1,2,3,4) are given in the on-line technical report [10].

Notice that p​(N^L​(𝜶^))𝑝subscript^𝑁𝐿^𝜶p({\hat{N}_{L}}(\hat{\bm{\alpha}})) denote the probability that the real number of clients with type αLsubscript𝛼𝐿\alpha_{L} is exactly the number N^L​(𝜶^)subscript^𝑁𝐿^𝜶{\hat{N}_{L}}(\hat{\bm{\alpha}}) of received number of reporting with type αLsubscript𝛼𝐿\alpha_{L}. This probability guarantees the incorporation of all reporting decisions into the reward function, thereby preventing clients from deviating. For instance, one cannot misreport for a higher reward, as such symmetric misreporting by other clients of the same type would result in a reduced reward for all. The penalty coefficients are designed through a comparison of clients’ equilibrium and socially optimal strategies, as seen in complete information scenarios. We also ensure the ex-ante budget balance by numerically designing the compensation payment in Definition 5 as:

q=𝔼𝜶∼𝒢N​(∑i∈𝒩pi​(𝜶^​(𝜶))−∑i∈𝒩ri​(𝜶^​(𝜶)))N.𝑞subscript𝔼similar-to𝜶superscript𝒢𝑁subscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝑝𝑖bold-^𝜶𝜶subscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝑟𝑖bold-^𝜶𝜶𝑁q=\frac{\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\alpha}\sim\mathcal{G}^{N}}\left(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}p_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}}(\bm{\alpha}))-\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}r_{i}(\bm{\hat{\alpha}}(\bm{\alpha}))\right)}{N}.

When we fix αLsubscript𝛼𝐿\alpha_{L} and αHsubscript𝛼𝐻\alpha_{H}, the parameter η𝜂\eta can be used to measure the divergence of clients’ types αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i}’s. When η=0.5𝜂0.5\eta=0.5, the diversity of clients’ type distribution is at its maximum. In our experiments on FL systems, we use a squared-SVM training model based on the original MNIST dataset with a loss function Fi(𝐰,𝐱j,yj)=λ2∥𝐰∥2+12max{0;1−yj𝐰T𝐱j}2F_{i}\left(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{x}_{j},y_{j}\right)=\frac{\lambda}{2}\|\mathbf{w}\|^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\max\left\{0;1-y_{j}\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{x}_{j}\right\}^{2} and λ𝜆\lambda is a constant. The training output is a binary model, and each client has 1000 training and 1000 testing data samples in each simulation round. Fig. 2 shows the social costs under our proposed pricing scheme in Definition 5 and the no-pricing benchmark. Both social costs increase as the variance of αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i}’s increases (i.e., η→0.5→𝜂0.5\eta\rightarrow 0.5), and our pricing scheme more significantly reduces the social cost compared to the benchmark with the maximum , which are consistent with our findings under complete information.

V Conclusion

In this paper, we adopt a game-theoretic perspective to examine clients’ privacy-preserving strategies in federated learning systems. We propose a two-stage game model to capture the interactions between clients and the server, and introduce pricing mechanisms to regulate clients’ selfish behaviors. Our pricing scheme is designed to reach the social optimum without verifying the actual noise-adding level. Even under incomplete information of clients’ private types, our mechanism incentivizes truthful reporting. Our analysis of the ratio of social costs shows that our approach outperforms the unguided one, with simulation results revealing greater improvement as the diversity of clients’ types increases.
